assemblyInfo.assemblyMethod: Hifiasm + Hi-C phasing v. 0.16.1 + galaxy2; yahs v. 1.2a + galaxy1

bioprojects.title: Hypanus sabinus (Atlantic stingray) genome, sHypSab1, haplotype 2

attributes.name: geo_loc_name
attributes.value: USA: Gulf of Mexico, near St Vincent Island, Florida

description.comment: The Atlantic stingray (Hypanus sabinus) is a species of stingray in the family Dasyatidae, common along the Atlantic coast of North America from Chesapeake Bay to Mexico, including brackish and freshwater habitats. It may be distinguished from other stingrays in the area by its relatively elongated snout. A homotypic synonomous species name is Dasyatis sabina. This sample is from a male in Gulf of Mexico, collected by Dean Grubbs, coordinated by Gavin Naylor at the University of Florida, and used to generate a high-quality reference genome for the Vertebrate Genomes Project (VGP). Sequencing and genome assembly were conducted at the Vertebrate Genomes Lab (VGL) at the Rockefeller University, led by Olivier Fedrigo and Erich D. Jarvis.
description.title: Animal sample from Hypanus sabinus (Atlantic stingray) for VGP genome, sHypSab1

biosample.geoLocName: USA: Gulf of Mexico, near St Vincent Island, Florida

sampleIds.label: Sample name
sampleIds.value: Animal sample from Hypanus sabinus (Atlantic stingray) for VGP genome, sHypSab1

assemblyInfo.comments: Chromosomes X1, X2 and Y were found based on coverage data. Chromosome Y was moved from hap2 into hap1 to have sex chromosomes in the same haplotype. Chromosome 32 is likely much larger, made up of many small scaffolds that could not be joined manually.
assemblyInfo.sequencingTech: PacBio Sequel II HiFi; Arima Hi-C v2
